name: DUMKE Rainer
Authors: Crepaz H., Ley L.Y., Dumke R.
Title: Cavity enhanced atomic magnetometry
Affiliations: Centre for Quantum Technologies, National University of Singapore, 3 Science Drive, Singapore, Singapore; Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, 21 Nanyang Link, Singapore, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Crepaz, H., Centre for Quantum Technologies, National University of Singapore, 3 Science Drive, Singapore, Singapore, Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, 21 Nanyang Link, Singapore, Singapore; Ley, L.Y., Centre for Quantum Technologies, National University of Singapore, 3 Science Drive, Singapore, Singapore, Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, 21 Nanyang Link, Singapore, Singapore; Dumke, R., Centre for Quantum Technologies, National University of Singapore, 3 Science Drive, Singapore, Singapore, Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, 21 Nanyang Link, Singapore, Singapore
Abstract: Atom sensing based on Faraday rotation is an indispensable method for precision measurements, universally suitable for both hot and cold atomic systems. Here we demonstrate an all-optical magnetometer where the optical cell for Faraday rotation spectroscopy is augmented with a low finesse cavity. Unlike in previous experiments, where specifically designed multipass cells had been employed, our scheme allows to use conventional, spherical vapour cells. Spherical shaped cells have the advantage that they can be effectively coated inside with a spin relaxation suppressing layer providing long spin coherence times without addition of a buffer gas. Cavity enhancement shows in an increase in optical polarization rotation and sensitivity compared to single-pass configurations.

name: DUMKE Rainer
Authors: Amico L., Aghamalyan D., Auksztol F., Crepaz H., Dumke R., Kwek L.C.
Title: Superfluid qubit systems with ring shaped optical lattices
Affiliations: CNR-MATIS-IMM, Dipartimento di Fisica e Astronomia, Via S. Abstract: We study an experimentally feasible qubit system employing neutral atomic currents. Our system is based on bosonic cold atoms trapped in ring-shaped optical lattice potentials. The lattice makes the system strictly one dimensional and it provides the infrastructure to realize a tunable ring-ring interaction. Our implementation combines the low decoherence rates of neutral cold atoms systems, overcoming single site addressing, with the robustness of topologically protected solid state Josephson flux qubits. Characteristic fluctuations in the magnetic fields affecting Josephson junction based flux qubits are expected to be minimized employing neutral atoms as flux carriers. By breaking the Galilean invariance we demonstrate how atomic currents through the lattice provide an implementation of a qubit. This is realized either by artificially creating a phase slip in a single ring, or by tunnel coupling of two homogeneous ring lattices. The single qubit infrastructure is experimentally investigated with tailored optical potentials. Indeed, we have experimentally realized scaled ring-lattice potentials that could host, in principle, n ? 10 of such ring-qubits, arranged in a stack configuration, along the laser beam propagation axis. An experimentally viable scheme of the two-ring-qubit is discussed, as well. Based on our analysis, we provide protocols to initialize, address, and read-out the qubit.

name: DUMKE Rainer
Authors: Siercke M., Oon F.E., Mohan A., Wang Z.W., Lim M.J., Dumke R.
Title: Density dependence of the ionization avalanche in ultracold Rydberg gases
Source title: Physical Review A - Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, 21 Nanyang Link, Singapore 637371, Singapore; Centre for Quantum Technologies, National University of Singapore, 3 Science Drive 2, Singapore 117543, Singapore; Department of Physics, Rowan University, 201 Mullica Hill Road, Glassboro, NJ 08028, United States

Abstract: We report on the behavior of the ionization avalanche in an ensemble of ultracold 87Rb atoms coupled to a high-lying Rydberg state and investigate extensions to the current model by including the effects of three-body recombination and plasma expansion. To separate the two effects we study the time dependence of the plasma formation at various densities as well as for different nS and nD states. At medium densities and low n we observe the onset of the avalanche as has been reported in other experiments, as well as a subsequent turn-off of the avalanche for longer excitation times, which we associate with plasma expansion. At higher densities and for higher-lying Rydberg states we observe a disappearance of the avalanche signature, which we attribute to three-body recombination. © 2014 American Physical Society.

name: DUMKE Rainer
Authors: Chan K.S., Siercke M., Hufnagel C., Dumke R.
Title: Adsorbate electric fields on a cryogenic atom chip
Affiliations: Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, 21 Nanyang Link, Singapore 637371, Singapore; Centre for Quantum Technologies, National University of Singapore, 3 Science Drive 2, Singapore 117543, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Chan, K.S., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, 21 Nanyang Link, Singapore 637371, Singapore; Siercke, M., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, 21 Nanyang Link, Singapore 637371, Singapore, Centre for Quantum Technologies, National University of Singapore, 3 Science Drive 2, Singapore 117543, Singapore; Hufnagel, C., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, 21 Nanyang Link, Singapore 637371, Singapore, Centre for Quantum Technologies, National University of Singapore, 3 Science Drive 2, Singapore 117543, Singapore; Dumke, R., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, 21 Nanyang Link, Singapore 637371, Singapore, Centre for Quantum Technologies, National University of Singapore, 3 Science Drive 2, Singapore 117543, Singapore
Abstract: We investigate the behavior of electric fields originating from adsorbates deposited on a cryogenic atom chip as it is cooled from room temperature to cryogenic temperature. Using Rydberg electromagnetically induced transparency, we measure the field strength versus distance from a 1 mm square of yttrium barium copper oxide (YBCO) patterned onto a yttria stabilized zirconia chip substrate. We find a localized and stable dipole field at room temperature and attribute it to a saturated layer of chemically adsorbed rubidium atoms on the YBCO. As the chip is cooled towards 83 K we observe a change in sign of the electric field as well as a transition from a localized to a delocalized dipole density. We relate these changes to the onset of physisorption on the chip surface when the van der Waals attraction overcomes the thermal desorption mechanisms. Our findings suggest that through careful selection of substrate materials, it may be possible to reduce the electric fields caused by atomic adsorption on chips, opening up experiments to controlled Rydberg-surface coupling schemes. © 2014 American Physical Society.
Index Keywords: Atomic adsorptions; Coupling scheme; Cryogenic temperatures; Desorption mechanism; Electromagnetically induced transparency; Room temperature; Substrate material; Van der Waals attraction; Adsorbates; Atoms; Barium compounds; Cryogenics; Van der Waals forces; Yttrium barium copper oxides; Electric fields

name: DUMKE Rainer
Authors: Siercke M., Chan K.S., Zhang B., Beian M., Lim M.J., Dumke R.
Title: Reconfigurable self-sufficient traps for ultracold atoms based on a superconducting square
Source title: Physical Review A - Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, 21 Nanyang Link, Singapore 637371, Singapore; Centre for Quantum Technologies, National University of Singapore, 3 Science Drive 2, Singapore 117543, Singapore; Department of Physics, Rowan University, 201 Mullica Hill Road, Glassboro, NJ 08028, United States
Authors with affiliations: Siercke, M., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, 21 Nanyang Link, Singapore 637371, Singapore, Centre for Quantum Technologies, National University of Singapore, 3 Science Drive 2, Singapore 117543, Singapore; Chan, K.S., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, 21 Nanyang Link, Singapore 637371, Singapore; Zhang, B., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, 21 Nanyang Link, Singapore 637371, Singapore, Centre for Quantum Technologies, National University of Singapore, 3 Science Drive 2, Singapore 117543, Singapore; Beian, M., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, 21 Nanyang Link, Singapore 637371, Singapore, Centre for Quantum Technologies, National University of Singapore, 3 Science Drive 2, Singapore 117543, Singapore; Lim, M.J., Department of Physics, Rowan University, 201 Mullica Hill Road, Glassboro, NJ 08028, United States; Dumke, R., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, 21 Nanyang Link, Singapore 637371, Singapore, Centre for Quantum Technologies, National University of Singapore, 3 Science Drive 2, Singapore 117543, Singapore
Abstract: We report on the trapping of ultracold atoms in the magnetic field formed entirely by persistent supercurrents induced in a thin film type-II superconducting square. The supercurrents are carried by vortices induced in the two-dimensional (2D) structure by applying two magnetic field pulses of varying amplitude perpendicular to its surface. This results in a self-sufficient quadrupole trap that does not require any externally applied fields. We investigate the trapping parameters for different supercurrent distributions. Furthermore, to demonstrate possible applications of these types of supercurrent traps we show how a central quadrupole trap can be split into four traps by use of a bias field, as predicted by Zhang. © 2012 American Physical Society.
Index Keywords: Applied field; Bias field; Magnetic field pulse; Quadrupole traps; Re-configurable; Superconducting square; Supercurrents; Trapping parameter; Two dimensional (2D) structure; Ultracold atoms; Magnetic fields; Superconducting materials; Two dimensional

name: DUMKE Rainer
Authors: Zhang B., Siercke M., Chan K.S., Beian M., Lim M.J., Dumke R.
Title: Magnetic confinement of neutral atoms based on patterned vortex distributions in superconducting disks and rings
Source title: Physical Review A - Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, 21 Nanyang Link, Singapore 637371, Singapore; Centre for Quantum Technologies, National University of Singapore, 3 Science Drive 2, Singapore 117543, Singapore; Department of Physics, Rowan University, 201 Mullica Hill Road, Glassboro, NJ 08028, United States

Abstract: We propose and analyze neutral atom traps generated by vortices imprinted by magnetic field pulse sequences in type II superconducting disks and rings. We compute the supercurrent distribution and magnetic field resulting from the vortices in the superconductor. Different patterns of vortices can be written by versatile loading field sequences. We discuss in detail procedures to generate quadrupole traps, self-sufficient traps, and ring traps based on superconducting disks and rings. The ease of creating these traps and the low current noise in supercurrent-carrying structures make our approach attractive for designing atom chip interferometers and probes. © 2012 American Physical Society.
Index Keywords: Atom chips; Low currents; Magnetic confinement; Magnetic field pulse; Neutral atoms; Quadrupole traps; Superconducting disks; Supercurrents; Type II; Vortex distribution; Atoms; Magnetic fields; Superconductivity; Vortex flow

name: DUMKE Rainer
Authors: Siercke M., Chan K.S., Zhang B., Lim M.J., Dumke R.
Title: Superconducting atom chips
Affiliations: Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore; Centre for Quantum Technologies, National University Singapore, Singapore; Rowan University, NJ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Siercke, M., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, Centre for Quantum Technologies, National University Singapore, Singapore; Chan, K.S., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore; Zhang, B., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, Centre for Quantum Technologies, National University Singapore, Singapore; Lim, M.J., Rowan University, NJ, United States; Dumke, R., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, Centre for Quantum Technologies, National University Singapore, Singapore
Abstract: We investigate superconducting chip structures for trapping and manipulating atoms. These structures are based on the average magnetic field of vortices induced in a type-II superconducting thin film. This magnetic field is the critical ingredient of the demonstrated vortex-based atom trap, which operate without transport current. We employ the hysteretic behavior of a superconducting thin film in the remanent state to generate different traps and flexible magnetic potentials for ultra-cold atoms. The experimental realization can be described by the Bean's critical-state method to model the vortex field through mesoscopic super currents induced in the thin strip. Various vortex patterns can be obtained by programming different loading-field and transport current sequences. Furthermore we will discuss the expected enhanced lifetime of atoms trapped close to a superconducting surface in comparison with a metallic surface. © 2011 AOS.

name: DUMKE Rainer
Authors: Siercke M., Chan K.S., Zhang B., Lim M.J., Dumke R.
Title: Superconducting atom chips
Source title: 2011 Int. Quantum Electron. Conf., IQEC 2011 and Conf. Lasers and Electro-Optics, CLEO Pacific Rim 2011 Incorporating the Australasian Conf. Optics, Lasers and Spectroscopy and the Australian Conf.
Affiliations: Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, Singapore; Centre for Quantum Technologies, National University Singapore, Singapore, Singapore; Rowan University, NJ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Siercke, M., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, Singapore, Centre for Quantum Technologies, National University Singapore, Singapore, Singapore; Chan, K.S., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, Singapore; Zhang, B., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, Singapore, Centre for Quantum Technologies, National University Singapore, Singapore, Singapore; Lim, M.J., Rowan University, NJ, United States; Dumke, R., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, Singapore, Centre for Quantum Technologies, National University Singapore, Singapore, Singapore
Abstract: We investigate superconducting chip structures for trapping and manipulating atoms. These structures are based on the average magnetic field of vortices induced in a type-II superconducting thin film. This magnetic field is the critical ingredient of the demonstrated vortex-based atom trap, which operate without transport current. We employ the hysteretic behavior of a superconducting thin film in the remanent state to generate different traps and flexible magnetic potentials for ultra-cold atoms. The experimental realization can be described by the Bean's critical-state method to model the vortex field through mesoscopic super currents induced in the thin strip. Various vortex patterns can be obtained by programming different loading-field and transport current sequences. Furthermore we will discuss the expected enhanced lifetime of atoms trapped close to a superconducting surface in comparison with a metallic surface. © 2011 IEEE.

name: DUMKE Rainer
Authors: Tandiono, Ohl S.-W., Ow D.S.W., Klaseboer E., Wong V.V., Dumke R., Ohl C.-D.
Title: Sonochemistry and sonoluminescence in microfluidics
Source title: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
Affiliations: Institute of High Performance Computing, 1 Fusionopolis Way, #16-16 Connexis, Singapore; Bioprocessing Technology Institute, 20 Biopolis Way, #06-01 Centros, Singapore; Division of Physics and Applied Physics, School of Physical and Mathematical Sciences, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Tandiono, Institute of High Performance Computing, 1 Fusionopolis Way, #16-16 Connexis, Singapore; Ohl, S.-W., Institute of High Performance Computing, 1 Fusionopolis Way, #16-16 Connexis, Singapore; Ow, D.S.W., Bioprocessing Technology Institute, 20 Biopolis Way, #06-01 Centros, Singapore; Klaseboer, E., Institute of High Performance Computing, 1 Fusionopolis Way, #16-16 Connexis, Singapore; Wong, V.V., Bioprocessing Technology Institute, 20 Biopolis Way, #06-01 Centros, Singapore; Dumke, R., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, School of Physical and Mathematical Sciences, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore; Ohl, C.-D., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, School of Physical and Mathematical Sciences, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore
Abstract: One way to focus the diffuse energy of a sound field in a liquid is by acoustically driving bubbles into nonlinear oscillation. A rapid and nearly adiabatic bubble collapse heats up the bubble interior and produces intense concentration of energy that is able to emit light (sonoluminescence) and to trigger chemical reactions (sonochemistry). Such phenomena have been extensively studied in bulk liquid. We present here a realization of sonoluminescence and sonochemistry created from bubbles confined within a narrow channel of polydimethylsiloxane-based microfluidic devices. In the microfluidics channels, the bubbles form a planar/pancake shape. During bubble collapse we find the formation of OH radicals and the emission of light. The chemical reactions are closely confined to gas-liquid interfaces that allow for spatial control of sonochemical reactions in lab-on-a-chip devices. The decay time of the light emitted from the sonochemical reaction is several orders faster than that in the bulk liquid. Multibubble sonoluminescence emission in contrast vanishes immediately as the sound field is stopped.

name: DUMKE Rainer

Title: Design of magnetic traps for neutral atoms with vortices in type-II superconducting microstructures
Source title: Physical Review A - Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, 21 Nanyang Link, Singapore 637371, Singapore; Centre for Quantum Technologies, National University of Singapore, 3 Science Drive 2, Singapore 117543, Singapore; Department of Physics and Astronomy, Rowan University, 201 Mullica Hill Road, NJ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, B., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, 21 Nanyang Link, Singapore 637371, Singapore; Fermani, R., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, 21 Nanyang Link, Singapore 637371, Singapore, Centre for Quantum Technologies, National University of Singapore, 3 Science Drive 2, Singapore 117543, Singapore; Müller, T., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, 21 Nanyang Link, Singapore 637371, Singapore, Centre for Quantum Technologies, National University of Singapore, 3 Science Drive 2, Singapore 117543, Singapore; Lim, M.J., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, 21 Nanyang Link, Singapore 637371, Singapore, Department of Physics and Astronomy, Rowan University, 201 Mullica Hill Road, NJ, United States; Dumke, R., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, 21 Nanyang Link, Singapore 637371, Singapore
Abstract: We design magnetic traps for atoms based on the average magnetic field of vortices induced in a type-II superconducting thin film. This magnetic field is the critical ingredient of the demonstrated vortex-based atom traps, which operate without transport current. We use Bean's critical-state method to model the vortex field through mesoscopic supercurrents induced in the thin strip. The resulting inhomogeneous magnetic fields are studied in detail and compared to those generated by multiple normally conducting wires with transport currents. Various vortex patterns can be obtained by programing different loading-field and transport-current sequences. These variable magnetic fields are employed to make versatile trapping potentials. © 2010 The American Physical Society.

Title: Programmable trap geometries with superconducting atom chips
Source title: Physical Review A - Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics

Abstract: We employ the hysteretic behavior of a superconducting thin film in the remanent state to generate different traps and flexible magnetic potentials for ultracold atoms. The trap geometry can be programed by externally applied fields. This approach for atom optics is demonstrated by three different trap types realized on a single microstructure: a Z-type trap, a double trap, and a bias-field-free trap. Our studies show that superconductors in the remanent state provide a versatile platform for atom optics and applications in ultracold quantum gases. © 2010 The American Physical Society.

name: DUMKE Rainer
Authors: Fermani R., Müller T., Zhang B., Lim M.J., Dumke R.
Title: Heating rate and spin flip lifetime due to near-field noise in layered superconducting atom chips
Source title: Journal of Physics B: Atomic, Molecular and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, 21 Nanyang Link, Singapore 637371, Singapore; Centre for Quantum Technologies, National University of Singapore, 3 Science Drive 2, Singapore 117543, Singapore; Department of Physics and Astronomy, Rowan University, 201 Mullica Hill Road, Glassboro, NJ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fermani, R., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, 21 Nanyang Link, Singapore 637371, Singapore, Centre for Quantum Technologies, National University of Singapore, 3 Science Drive 2, Singapore 117543, Singapore; Müller, T., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, 21 Nanyang Link, Singapore 637371, Singapore, Centre for Quantum Technologies, National University of Singapore, 3 Science Drive 2, Singapore 117543, Singapore; Zhang, B., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, 21 Nanyang Link, Singapore 637371, Singapore; Lim, M.J., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, 21 Nanyang Link, Singapore 637371, Singapore, Department of Physics and Astronomy, Rowan University, 201 Mullica Hill Road, Glassboro, NJ, United States; Dumke, R., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, Nanyang Technological University, 21 Nanyang Link, Singapore 637371, Singapore
Abstract: We investigate theoretically the heating rate and spin flip lifetimes due to near-field noise for atoms trapped close to layered superconducting structures with the superconductor in the Meissner state. In particular, we compare the case of a gold layer deposited above a superconductor with the case of a bare superconductor. We study a niobium-based and a YBa2Cu 3O7 - x (YBCO)-based chip. For both niobium and YBCO chips at a temperature of 4.2 K, we find that the deposition of the gold layer can have a significant impact on the heating rate and spin flip lifetime, as a result of the increase of the near-field noise. At a chip temperature of 77 K, this effect is less pronounced for the YBCO chip. © 2010 IOP Publishing Ltd.

Authors: Müller T., Zhang B., Fermani R., Chan K.S., Wang Z.W., Zhang C.B., Lim M.J., Dumke R.
Title: Trapping of ultra-cold atoms with the magnetic field of vortices in a thin-film superconducting micro-structure
Affiliations: Division of Physics and Applied Physics, School of Physical and Mathematical Sciences, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore 637371, Singapore; Centre for Quantum Technologies, National University of Singapore, 3 Science Drive 2, Singapore 117543, Singapore; Department of Physics and Astronomy, Rowan University, 201 Mullica Hill Road, Glassboro, NJ, United States

Abstract: We store and control ultra-cold atoms in a new type of trap using the magnetic fields of vortices in a high-temperature superconducting micro-structure. We generate the attractive trapping potential for the atoms by combining the magnetic field of a superconductor in the remanent state with external homogeneous magnetic fields. We show the control of crucial atom trap characteristics such as an efficient intrinsic loading mechanism, spatial positioning of the trapped atoms and the vortex density in the superconductor. The measured trap characteristics are in good agreement with our numerical simulations. © IOP Publishing Ltd and Deutsche Physikalische Gesellschaft.

name: DUMKE Rainer
Authors: Müller T., Wu X., Mohan A., Eyvazov A., Wu Y., Dumke R.
Title: Towards a guided atom interferometer based on a superconducting atom chip
Affiliations: Division of Physics and Applied Physics, School of Physical and Mathematical Sciences, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore 637371, Singapore; Physics Department, Faculty of Science, National University of Singapore, Singapore 117542, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Müller, T., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, School of Physical and Mathematical Sciences, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore 637371, Singapore, Physics Department, Faculty of Science, National University of Singapore, Singapore 117542, Singapore; Wu, X., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, School of Physical and Mathematical Sciences, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore 637371, Singapore; Mohan, A., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, School of Physical and Mathematical Sciences, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore 637371, Singapore; Eyvazov, A., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, School of Physical and Mathematical Sciences, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore 637371, Singapore; Wu, Y., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, School of Physical and Mathematical Sciences, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore 637371, Singapore; Dumke, R., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, School of Physical and Mathematical Sciences, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore 637371, Singapore
Abstract: We evaluate the realization of a novel geometry of a guided atom interferometer based on a high-temperature superconducting microstructure. The interferometer-type structure is obtained with a guiding potential realized by two current carrying superconducting wires in combination with a closed superconducting loop sustaining a persistent current. We present the layout and realization of our superconducting atom chip. By employing simulations, we discuss the critical parameters of the interferometer guide in particular near the splitting regions of the matter waves. Based on measurements of the relevant chip properties, we discuss the application of a compact and reliable on-chip atom interferometer. © IOP Publishing Ltd and Deutsche Physikalische Gesellschaft.

name: DUMKE Rainer
Authors: Wang Y., Liu T., Stejskal A., Zhao Y., Dumke R., Zhang J., Lu Z., Wang L., Dong T.
Title: Absolute frequency measurements of the clock transition 5s21S0-5s5p 3P0 in singly ionized indium
Source title: Beijing Daxue Xuebao (Ziran Kexue Ban)/Acta Scientiarum Naturalium Universitatis Pekinensis
Affiliations: Key Laboratory of Quantum Information and Measurements of Ministry of Education, School of Electronics Engineering and Computer Science, Peking University, Beijing 100871, China; Max-Planck Research Group, Institute of Optics, Information and Photonics, University Erlangen-Nuremberg,, Erlangen 91058, Germany; Nanyang Technological University, Singapore 637616, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Wang, Y., Key Laboratory of Quantum Information and Measurements of Ministry of Education, School of Electronics Engineering and Computer Science, Peking University, Beijing 100871, China, Max-Planck Research Group, Institute of Optics, Information and Photonics, University Erlangen-Nuremberg,, Erlangen 91058, Germany; Liu, T., Max-Planck Research Group, Institute of Optics, Information and Photonics, University Erlangen-Nuremberg,, Erlangen 91058, Germany; Stejskal, A., Max-Planck Research Group, Institute of Optics, Information and Photonics, University Erlangen-Nuremberg,, Erlangen 91058, Germany; Zhao, Y., Max-Planck Research Group, Institute of Optics, Information and Photonics, University Erlangen-Nuremberg,, Erlangen 91058, Germany; Dumke, R., Max-Planck Research Group, Institute of Optics, Information and Photonics, University Erlangen-Nuremberg,, Erlangen 91058, Germany, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore 637616, Singapore; Zhang, J., Max-Planck Research Group, Institute of Optics, Information and Photonics, University Erlangen-Nuremberg,, Erlangen 91058, Germany; Lu, Z., Max-Planck Research Group, Institute of Optics, Information and Photonics, University Erlangen-Nuremberg,, Erlangen 91058, Germany; Wang, L., Key Laboratory of Quantum Information and Measurements of Ministry of Education, School of Electronics Engineering and Computer Science, Peking University, Beijing 100871, China, Max-Planck Research Group, Institute of Optics, Information and Photonics, University Erlangen-Nuremberg,, Erlangen 91058, Germany; Dong, T., Key Laboratory of Quantum Information and Measurements of Ministry of Education, School of Electronics Engineering and Computer Science, Peking University, Beijing 100871, China
Abstract: The authors report on the current status of the optical frequency standard based on a single 115In+ ion. A single Indium ion is trapped in a Paul-Straubel type trap and cooled by sideband cooling to its lowest vibrational states. To interrogate the 5s2 1S0-5s5p 3P0 clock transition with high accuracy, the authors demonstrate a Hz-level level laser system resonant to this transition. The Absolute frequency measurement is performed with the help of a femtosecond laser referenced to a commercial cesium, atomic clock. 20 sessions measurements are achieved. The relative fractional uncertainty is 5.0 × 10-14.
Author Keywords: Absolute frequency measurement; Femtosecond laser; Single ion

Title: Progress toward an optical frequency standard based on a single indium ion
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE International Frequency Control Symposium and Exposition
Affiliations: Max Planck Research Group, Institute of Optics, Information and Photonics, University Erlangen-Nuremberg, Günther-Scharowsky-Str. 1 / Bau 24, 91058 Erlangen, Germany; Max Planck Institute of Quantum Optics, Hans-Kopfermann-Str. 1, 85748 Garching, Germany

Abstract: We report on the current status of the optical frequency standard based on a single 115In+ ion. A single Indium ion is being trapped in a Paul-Strauble type trap and cooled in combination of Doppler cooling and sideband cooling to its lowest vibrational states. To interrogate the 1S0-3P0 clock transition with high accuracy we demonstrate a Hz-level laser system resonant to this transition. With the current setup we are able to achieve a measured linewidth of the clock transition of 260 Hz. The statistical uncertainty of the absolute frequency measurement is 3×10-13, limited mainly by our reference frequency standard. © 2006 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Indium; Laser applications; Metal ions; Resonance; Hz-level laser system; Sideband cooling; Standards

Authors: Zhang J., Lu Z.H., Wang Y.H., Liu T., Stejskal A., Zhao Y.N., Wang L.J., Dumke R.
Title: Absolute mode number determination of frequency combs
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE International Frequency Control Symposium and Exposition
Affiliations: Institute of Optics, Information and Photonics, Max-Planck Research Group, University Erlangen-Nuremberg, Erlangen, Germany; School of Physical and Mathematical Sciences, Nanyang Technological University, Nanyang, Singapore

Abstract: We demonstrate a method to determine the absolute mode number of a frequency comb when it is used for high precision laser frequency measurement, without the help of wavemeters. Our technique involves changing the repetition rate of the frequency comb in a two-steps process. Guidelines for choosing the correct repetition rates for different laser linewidths are given. As a demonstration, the absolute frequencies of two lasers with different linewidths are measured with our method. © 2007 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Cantilever beams; Ontology; Frequency combs; Mode numbers; Repetition rates; Lasers

Title: Progress toward a single indium ion optical frequency standard
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE International Frequency Control Symposium and Exposition
Affiliations: Institute of Optics, Information and Photonics, Max-Planck Research Group, University Erlangen-Nuremberg, 91058 Erlangen, Germany; School of Physical and Mathematical Sciences, Nanyang Technological University, Nanyang Walk Block 5, Level 3, Singapore 637616, Singapore; Max Planck Institute of Quantum Optics, Hans-Kopfermann-Str. 1, 85748 Garching, Germany

Abstract: We report an improved absolute frequency measurement of the 5s2 1S0 - 5s5p 3P0 narrowline clock transition at 236.5 nm, for a single trapped and laser cooled 115In+. Using a narrowline laser as the local oscillator, a linewidth of 43 Hz for the transition is resolved. For absolute frequency measurement we use an optical frequency comb referenced to a cesium clock. The transition frequency is found to be 1, 267, 402, 452, 900, 967 (63) Hz, averaged over 13 days of separate measurements. The accuracy is about 5.0 × 10-14. And a preliminary absolute frequency measurement is shown with a Hydrogen maser as the reference. We discuss possibilities for further improvement. © 2007 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Absolute frequency; European; Frequency controls; Frequency standards

Abstract: We report greater than two orders of magnitude improvements in the absolute frequency and isotope shift measurements of the In+ 5s2 1S0 (F = 9/2)-5s5p 3P1 (F = 11/2) transition near 230.6 nm. The laser-induced fluorescence from a single In + in a radio-frequency trap is detected. The fourth-harmonic of a semiconductor laser is used as the light source. The absolute frequency is measured with the help of a frequency comb referenced to a Cs atomic clock. The resulting transition frequencies for isotopes 115In+ and 113In+ are measured to be 1?299?648?954. 54(10) MHz and 1?299?649?585.36(16) MHz, respectively. The deduced cooling transition frequency difference is 630.82(19) MHz. By taking into account of the hyperfine interaction, the isotope shift is calculated to be 695.76(1.68) MHz. © 2007 EDP Sciences/Società Italiana di Fisica/Springer-Verlag.

Abstract: We demonstrate a method to determine the absolute mode number of a frequency comb when it is used for high-precision laser frequency measurement, without the help of wavemeters. Our technique involves changing the repetition rate of the frequency comb in a two-step process. Guidelines for choosing the correct repetition rates for different laser linewidths are given. As a demonstration, the absolute frequencies of two lasers with different linewidths are measured with our method. © 2007 MAIK "Nauka/Interperiodica".
Index Keywords: Measurement theory; Microwave measurement; Wavemeters; Frequency comb; High precision laser frequency measurement; Laser linewidths; Optical frequency conversion

Abstract: We report on an improved absolute frequency measurement of the 5s 2 1 S 00-5s5p 3 P 0 narrowline clock transition at 236.5 nm, for a single, trapped, and laser-cooled 115In ion. Using a narrowline laser as the local oscillator, a linewidth of 43 Hz for the transition is resolved. The uncertainty of the transition frequency's centroid is 18 Hz, leading to a fractional uncertainty of 1.4 × 10-14. For absolute frequency measurement, we use an optical frequency comb locked to a cesium clock as the reference. The transition frequency is found to be 1267402452900967(63) Hz, averaged over 13 days of separate measurements. The accuracy is about 5.0 × 10-14. We discuss possibilities for further improvement. © 2007 MAIK "Nauka/Interperiodica".

name: DUMKE Rainer
Authors: Wang Y.H., Dumke R., Liu T., Stejskal A., Zhao Y.N., Zhang J., Lu Z.H., Wang L.J., Becker Th., Walther H.
Title: Absolute frequency measurement and high resolution spectroscopy of 115In+ 5s2 1S0-5s5p 3P0 narrowline transition
Affiliations: Max Planck Research Group, Institute of Optics, Information and Photonics, University Erlangen-Nuremberg, Gunther-Scharowsky-Str. 1, /Bau24, 91058 Erlangen, Germany; School of Physical and Mathematical Sciences, Nanyang Technological University, 1 Nanyang Walk Block 5, Level 3, Singapore, 637616, Singapore; Max Planck Institute of Quantum Optics, Hans-Kopfermann-Str. 1, 85748 Garching, Germany

Abstract: We measure the frequency of the 5s2 1S0-5s5p 3P0 narrowline clock transition at 236.5 nm, for a single, trapped and laser cooled 115In+ ion. In the experiment, an ultra-narrow linewidth laser (<1.34 Hz at 3 s integration time) is used to interrogate the clock transition for high resolution spectroscopy. A linewidth of 43 Hz of the clock transition is observed. The uncertainty of the line centroid is 18 Hz, leading to a fractional uncertainty of 1.4 × 10- 14. The frequency is measured by using an optical frequency comb referenced to a cesium clock. The transition frequency is found to be 1, 267, 402, 452, 901.265 (256) kHz, averaged over 13 days of separate measurement. The accuracy of 2.35 × 10- 13 is due to the reference cesium clock calibrated against UTC time. We discuss ways for further improvements. © 2007 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Absolute frequency measurement; High resolution spectroscopy; Ion trapping; Optical frequency standard

name: DUMKE Rainer
Authors: Liu T., Wang Y.H., Dumke R., Stejskal A., Zhao Y.N., Zhang J., Lu Z.H., Wang L.J., Becker Th., Walther H.
Title: Narrow linewidth light source for an ultraviolet optical frequency standard
Source title: Applied Physics B: Lasers and Optics
Affiliations: Max Planck Research Group, Institute of Optics, Information and Photonics, University Erlangen-Nuremberg, Günther-Scharowsky-Str. 1/Bau24, 91058 Erlangen, Germany; Max Planck Institute of Quantum Optics, Hans-Kopfermann-Str. 1, 85748 Garching, Germany; School of Physical and Mathematical Sciences, Nanyang Technological University, 1 Nanyang Walk Block 5, Level 3, Singapore 637616, Singapore

Abstract: We report an ultra-narrow linewidth light source applicable for a frequency standard in the ultraviolet. The laser is a Nd:YAG laser that emits at 946 nm with 300-mW output power. It is locked to a high-finesse cavity. The minimum Allan deviation is 1.3×10-14 for an integration time of 1 s, which corresponds to a laser linewidth of 2.8 Hz. The cavity drift is measured by a frequency comb and a single-ion spectrum for different time scales. In order to investigate broadening mechanisms due to the fiber transport and doubling systems, the laser light is frequency doubled with two independent systems and compared. The measured minimum beat-note between the two laser fields is less than 1 Hz. By carrying out a high-resolution scan on a trapped single indium ion, we observe a linewidth of 260 Hz on the ion clock transition. Possible reasons for the broadening effects are discussed. © Springer-Verlag 2007.
Index Keywords: Laser beams; Linewidth; Natural frequencies; Optical resolving power; Ultraviolet radiation; Allan deviation; Clock transition; Optical frequency; Light sources

Authors: Zhang J., Lu Z.H., Wang Y.H., Liu T., Stejskal A., Zhao Y.N., Wang L.J., Dumke R.

name: DUMKE Rainer
Authors: Dumke R., Johanning M., Gomez E., Weinstein J.D., Jones K.M., Lett P.D.
Title: All-optical generation and photoassociative probing of sodium Bose-Einstein condensates
Affiliations: Atomic Physics Division, National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, MD 20899-8424, United States; Institute of Optics, Information and Photonics, Gunther-Scharowsky-Str. 1, Bau 24, 91058 Erlangen, Germany; Fachbereich Physik, Emmy-Noether-Campus, Universität Siegen, Walter-Flex-Straße 3, D-57068 Siegen, Germany; C-INC MS J514, LOS Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Physics Department, Williams College, Williamstown, MA 01267, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dumke, R., Atomic Physics Division, National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, MD 20899-8424, United States, Institute of Optics, Information and Photonics, Gunther-Scharowsky-Str. 1, Bau 24, 91058 Erlangen, Germany; Johanning, M., Atomic Physics Division, National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, MD 20899-8424, United States, Fachbereich Physik, Emmy-Noether-Campus, Universität Siegen, Walter-Flex-Straße 3, D-57068 Siegen, Germany; Gomez, E., Atomic Physics Division, National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, MD 20899-8424, United States; Weinstein, J.D., Atomic Physics Division, National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, MD 20899-8424, United States, C-INC MS J514, LOS Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Jones, K.M., Atomic Physics Division, National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, MD 20899-8424, United States, Physics Department, Williams College, Williamstown, MA 01267, United States; Lett, P.D., Atomic Physics Division, National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, MD 20899-8424, United States
Abstract: We demonstrate an all-optical technique to evaporatively produce sodium Bose-Einstein condensates (BEC). We use a crossed-dipole trap formed from light near 1 ?m, and a simple ramp of the intensity to force evaporation. In addition, we introduce photoassociation as diagnostic of the trap loading process, and show that it can be used to detect the onset of BEC. Finally, we demonstrate the straightforward production of multiple traps with condensates using this technique, and that some control over the spinor state of the BEC is achieved by positioning the trap as well. © IOP Publishing Ltd and Deutsche Physikalische Gesellschaft.
Index Keywords: Diagnosis; Evaporation; Hole traps; Lighting; Optical systems; Sodium; Bose-Einstein condensates (BEC); Force evaporation; Optical generation; Photoassociative probing; Gas condensates

name: DUMKE Rainer
Authors: Johanning M., Dumke R., Weinstein J.D., Jones K.M., Lett P.D.
Title: Dark superposition states between ultra-cold atoms and molecules generated by photoassociation
Affiliations: Atomic Physics Division, National Institute for Standards and Technology, Stop 8424, 100 Bureau Drive, Gaithersburg, MD 20899-8424, United States; Physics Department, Williams College, Williamstown, MA 01267, United States
Authors with affiliations: Johanning, M., Atomic Physics Division, National Institute for Standards and Technology, Stop 8424, 100 Bureau Drive, Gaithersburg, MD 20899-8424, United States; Dumke, R., Atomic Physics Division, National Institute for Standards and Technology, Stop 8424, 100 Bureau Drive, Gaithersburg, MD 20899-8424, United States; Weinstein, J.D., Atomic Physics Division, National Institute for Standards and Technology, Stop 8424, 100 Bureau Drive, Gaithersburg, MD 20899-8424, United States; Jones, K.M., Atomic Physics Division, National Institute for Standards and Technology, Stop 8424, 100 Bureau Drive, Gaithersburg, MD 20899-8424, United States, Physics Department, Williams College, Williamstown, MA 01267, United States; Lett, P.D., Atomic Physics Division, National Institute for Standards and Technology, Stop 8424, 100 Bureau Drive, Gaithersburg, MD 20899-8424, United States
Abstract: We have performed a type of Autler-Townes spectroscopy to investigate the coherence properties between ultra-cold atoms and sodium-dimers generated by photoassociation. Ultra-cold molecules have recently generated new interest due to the accomplishment of Bose-Einstein-condensation (BEC) of molecules and offer a variety of new approaches for a better understanding of atomic and molecular physics, precision measurements and fundamental research. In our experiment photoassociation [1] is used to couple free collisional states of ultra-cold, magnetically trapped sodium atoms to bound excited molecular states (see fig. 1). The excited molecules can spontaneously decay to atoms or molecules in the electronic ground state. Efficient detection of the excited state molecules produced is possible by ionizing the excited state with an additional cw-laser and detecting the ions by means of a microchannel plate (MCP). Alternatively molecules in the electronic ground state can be detected by resonant two-photon ionization. With an additional laser the excited state of the molecule can be coupled to the long lived electronic ground state. When this coupling laser is kept on resonance while the photoassociation laser is scanned a splitting of the photoassociation line is observed (see fig. 2). The coupling-laser creates a coherent superposition of the two ground states of the lambda system and the population in the excited state is reduced. This effect is analogous to the Autler-Townes-effect [2] and to electromagnetically induced transparency (EIT) [3]. In contrast to EIT one of the ground states is a (discrete) molecular state whereas the second ground state belongs to a continuum of free scattering states with different collisional energies. We observe spectral features as narrow as 5 MHz, which is well below the natural linewidth of the excited molecular level of about 20 MHz. The occurrence of subnatural linewidths demonstrates the formation of a dark superposition state and yields information about the coherence time between the free and bound atoms. The observed linewidth and the population of this state are limited by the temperature of the atoms in our experiment. We are currently setting up a new apparatus to produce lower temperature atomic samples and achieve BEC by evaporation in optical traps. © 2005 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Bose-Einstein-condensation (BEC); Dark superposition states; Microchannel plate (MCP); Photoassociation; Ground state; Hole traps; Laser pulses; Molecular physics; Photoreactivity; Plasma collision processes; Atomic physics
References: Weiner, J., Bagnato, V.S., Zilio, S., Julienne, P.S., (1999) Rev. Mod. Phys, 71, p. 1; Autler, S.H., Townes, C.H., (1955) Phys. Rev, 100, p. 703; Arimondo, E., (1996) Progress in Optics, 35, p. 257
Correspondence Address: Johanning, M.; Atomic Physics Division, National Institute for Standards and Technology, 100 Bureau Drive, Stop 8424, Gaithersburg, MD 20899-8424, United States
Conference name: 2005 European Quantum Electronics Conference, EQEC '05

name: DUMKE Rainer
Authors: Dumke R., Weinstein J.D., Johanning M., Jones K.M., Lett P.D.
Title: Sub-natural-linewidth quantum interference features observed in photoassociation of a thermal gas
Source title: Physical Review A - Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Atomic Physics Division, National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, MD 20899-8424, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dumke, R., Atomic Physics Division, National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, MD 20899-8424, United States; Weinstein, J.D., Atomic Physics Division, National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, MD 20899-8424, United States; Johanning, M., Atomic Physics Division, National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, MD 20899-8424, United States; Jones, K.M., Atomic Physics Division, National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, MD 20899-8424, United States; Lett, P.D., Atomic Physics Division, National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, MD 20899-8424, United States
Abstract: By driving photoassociation transitions, we form electronically excited molecules (Na2*) from ultracold (50-300?K) Na atoms. Using a second laser to drive transitions from the excited state to a level in the molecular ground state, we are able to split the photoassociation line and observe features with a width smaller than the natural linewidth of the excited molecular state. The quantum interference which gives rise to this effect is analogous to that which leads to electromagnetically induced transparency in three-level atomic ? systems, but here one of the ground states is a pair of free atoms while the other is a bound molecule. The linewidth is limited primarily by the finite temperature of the atoms. © 2005 The American Physical Society.
Index Keywords: Photoassociation; Quantum interference; Thermal gas; Ground state; Magnetoelectric effects; Quantum interference phenomena; Sodium; Quantum theory

Abstract: We report all-optical Bose-Einstein-Condensation of sodium in a far-detuned crossed-dipoletrap. Sub-doppler-cooled sodium atoms are loaded into a crossed-dipole-trap and subsequently condensed by optical evaporation which yields condensates of 150000 atoms distributed over several spin-states. © 2005 Optical Society of America.

Abstract: By driving photoassociation transitions with continuous-wave lasers, we stateselectively form excited-state molecules from ultra cold atoms. Using a second laser to drive transitions from the excited molecular state to another long-lived molecular state, we are able to observe an interference dip narrower than the natural linewidth of the excited molecular state. The linewidth of the dip is strongly effected by the temperature of the atoms. To reach smaller linewidths we have set up an all optical BEC. © 2005 Optical Society of America.

Affiliations: Inst. für Theoretische Physik, Universität Hannover, 30167 Hannover, Germany; Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, 30167 Hannover, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Kreutzmann, H., Inst. für Theoretische Physik, Universität Hannover, 30167 Hannover, Germany; Poulsen, U.V., Inst. für Theoretische Physik, Universität Hannover, 30167 Hannover, Germany; Lewenstein, M., Inst. für Theoretische Physik, Universität Hannover, 30167 Hannover, Germany; Dumke, R., Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, 30167 Hannover, Germany; Ertmer, W., Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, 30167 Hannover, Germany; Birkl, G., Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, 30167 Hannover, Germany; Sanpera, A., Inst. für Theoretische Physik, Universität Hannover, 30167 Hannover, Germany
Abstract: The coherent properties of beam splitters and Mach-Zehnder interferometers for guided neutral atoms were studied. The feasibility of guided-atom interferometry was provided strongly by simulations. The X-shaped beam splitter act analogously to a 'color filter'. It was found that temperature was not a limitation for the observation of interference fringes and coherence was preserved. Analysis shows that the observable fringe visibility was reduced by the experimental noise with predicted visibilities.

Abstract: Application of microoptical elements to quantum information processing with atoms and discussion of the inherent advantages and the potential of the new approach are presented. As one example, applicability of arrays of microfabricated lenses to create multiple far-detuned dipole traps for storing and manipulating qubits inscribed into atoms are experimentally investigated.

Title: Interferometer-type structures for guided atoms
Affiliations: Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Weifengarten 1, Hannover, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Dumke, R., Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Weifengarten 1, Hannover, Germany; Müther, T., Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Weifengarten 1, Hannover, Germany; Schamberg, F., Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Weifengarten 1, Hannover, Germany; Volk, M., Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Weifengarten 1, Hannover, Germany; Ertmer, W., Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Weifengarten 1, Hannover, Germany; Birkl, G., Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Weifengarten 1, Hannover, Germany
Abstract: Interferometer-type guiding structures is demonstrated for neutral atoms based on dipole potentials created by micro-fabricated optical systems. As a central element, an array of atom waveguides is used, being formed by focusing a red-detuned laser beam with an array of cylindrical microlenses. Combining two of these arrays, X-shaped beam splitters and more complex systems like the geometries for Mach-Zehnder and Michelson-type interferometers for atoms are realized. With these elements versatile and integrated atom optical devices can be created in a compact fashion.
Index Keywords: Atoms; Interferometers; Laser beams; Microlenses; Quantum electronics; Cylindrical microlense; Detuned laser beams; Dipole potential; Guiding structures; Integrated atom; Michelson-type interferometers; Neutral atoms; Type structures; Atom lasers

Publisher: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers Inc.
Conference name: European Quantum Electronics Conference, EQEC 2003

Authors: Dumke R., Müther T., Volk M., Ertmer W., Birkl G.
Title: Micro-Optics Advances Quantum Computing and Integrated Atom Optics
Affiliations: Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Hannover, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Dumke, R., Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Hannover, Germany; Müther, T., Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Hannover, Germany; Volk, M., Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Hannover, Germany; Ertmer, W., Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Hannover, Germany; Birkl, G., Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Hannover, Germany
Abstract: The application of micro- and nano-optics on quantum optics, quantum information processing and matter wave optics was studied. Microfabricated optical systems were used to create light fields that trap and guide neutral atoms as a result of the optical dipole force experienced by the atoms. The micro-optic elements were used to generate waveguides, beam splitters and interferometer-type geometries for guided atoms. The use of microfabricated and nanofabricated optical, magnetic and electric systems will establish the newly emerging field of integrated atom optics.
Index Keywords: Integrated optics; Interferometers; Laser applications; Microlenses; Optical beam splitters; Optical waveguides; Quantum optics; Laser cooling; Quantum computing; Microoptics

name: DUMKE Rainer
Authors: Dumke R., Volk M., Müther T., Buchkremer F.B.J., Birkl G., Ertmer W.
Title: Micro-optical realization of arrays of selectively addressable dipole traps: A scalable configuration for quantum computation with atomic qubits
Affiliations: Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Welfengarten 1, D-30167 Hannover, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Dumke, R., Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Welfengarten 1, D-30167 Hannover, Germany; Volk, M., Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Welfengarten 1, D-30167 Hannover, Germany; Müther, T., Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Welfengarten 1, D-30167 Hannover, Germany; Buchkremer, F.B.J., Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Welfengarten 1, D-30167 Hannover, Germany; Birkl, G., Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Welfengarten 1, D-30167 Hannover, Germany; Ertmer, W., Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Welfengarten 1, D-30167 Hannover, Germany
Abstract: The implementation of microfabricated optical systems for quantum computing purposes with atoms was presented. Neutral atoms were trapped in one- and two-dimensional arrays of far-detuned dipole traps created by focusing a red-detuned laser beam with microfabricated array of microlenses. Each trap acted as a memory site for quantum information encoded in the two hyperfine ground states of the atoms. The results showed that the sideband cooling of atoms to the vibrational ground state of the trap arrays is possible with the achievable vibrational frequencies.

name: DUMKE Rainer
Authors: Buchkremer F.B.J., Dumke R., Volk M., Müther T., Birkl G., Ertmer W.
Title: Quantum information processing with microfabricated optical elements
Affiliations: Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Welfengarten 1, Hannover D-30167, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Buchkremer, F.B.J., Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Welfengarten 1, Hannover D-30167, Germany; Dumke, R., Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Welfengarten 1, Hannover D-30167, Germany; Volk, M., Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Welfengarten 1, Hannover D-30167, Germany; Müther, T., Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Welfengarten 1, Hannover D-30167, Germany; Birkl, G., Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Welfengarten 1, Hannover D-30167, Germany; Ertmer, W., Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Welfengarten 1, Hannover D-30167, Germany
Abstract: We discuss a new direction in the field of quantum information processing with neutral atoms. It is based on the use of microfabricated optical elements. With these elements versatile and integrated atom optical devices can be created in a compact fashion. This approach opens the possibility to scale, parallelize, and miniaturize configurations for quantum information processing with neutral atoms. The exploitation of the unique features of the quantum mechanical behavior of matter waves and the capabilities of powerful state-of-the-art micro- and nanofabrication techniques lend this approach a special attraction.

name: DUMKE Rainer
Authors: Birkl G., Buchkremer F.B.J., Dumke R., Ertmer W.
Title: Atom optics with microfabricated optical elements
Affiliations: Institut Für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Welfengarten 1, 30167 Hannover, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Birkl, G., Institut Für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Welfengarten 1, 30167 Hannover, Germany; Buchkremer, F.B.J., Institut Für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Welfengarten 1, 30167 Hannover, Germany; Dumke, R., Institut Für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Welfengarten 1, 30167 Hannover, Germany; Ertmer, W., Institut Für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Welfengarten 1, 30167 Hannover, Germany
Abstract: We introduce a new direction in the field of atom optics, atom interferometry, and neutral-atom quantum information processing. It is based on the use of microfabricated optical elements. With these elements versatile and integrated atom optical devices can be created in a compact fashion. This approach opens the possibility to scale, parallelize, and miniaturize atom optics for new investigations in fundamental research and application. It will lead to new, compact sources of ultracold atoms, compact sensors based on matter wave interference and new approaches towards quantum computing with neutral atoms. The exploitation of the unique features of the quantum mechanical behavior of matter waves and the capabilities of powerful state-of-the-art micro- and nanofabrication techniques lend this approach a special attraction. © 2001 Elsevier Science B.V.
Author Keywords: Atom interferometry; Atom optics; Laser cooling; Microfabrication; Microoptics; Quantum information processing

Authors: Killian T.C., Lim M.J., Kulin S., Dumke R., Bergeson S.D., Rolston S.L.
Title: Formation of Rydberg atoms in an expanding ultracold neutral plasma
Affiliations: Natl. Inst. of Std. and Technology, Gaithersburg, MD 20899-8424, United States; Department of Physics and Astronomy, Brigham Young University, Provo, UT 84602-4640, United States
Authors with affiliations: Killian, T.C., Natl. Inst. of Std. and Technology, Gaithersburg, MD 20899-8424, United States; Lim, M.J., Natl. Inst. of Std. and Technology, Gaithersburg, MD 20899-8424, United States; Bergeson, S.D., Natl. Inst. of Std. and Technology, Gaithersburg, MD 20899-8424, United States, Department of Physics and Astronomy, Brigham Young University, Provo, UT 84602-4640, United States; Rolston, S.L., Natl. Inst. of Std. and Technology, Gaithersburg, MD 20899-8424, United States
Abstract: Rydberg atoms recombination in an ultracold neutral plasma was observed. At temperatures ranging from 1-1000 K, and densities from 105-1010 cm-3, up to 20% of the initially free charges recombined on a time scale of 100 ?s. The Rydberg atom distributions as a function of principal quantum number and time were determined for a wide range of initial conditions.

name: DUMKE Rainer
Authors: Lim M.J., Killian T.C., Kulin S., Dumke R., Rolston S.L., Bergeson S.D.
Title: Recombination in an expanding ultracold plasma
Source title: Technical Digest - Summaries of Papers Presented at the Quantum Electronics and Laser Science Conference, QELS 2001
Affiliations: Nat. Inst. of Stand. and Technol., Gaithersburg, MD, United States; Brigham Young University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lim, M.J., Nat. Inst. of Stand. and Technol., Gaithersburg, MD, United States; Killian, T.C., Nat. Inst. of Stand. and Technol., Gaithersburg, MD, United States; Kulin, S., Nat. Inst. of Stand. and Technol., Gaithersburg, MD, United States; Dumke, R., Nat. Inst. of Stand. and Technol., Gaithersburg, MD, United States; Rolston, S.L., Nat. Inst. of Stand. and Technol., Gaithersburg, MD, United States; Bergeson, S.D., Brigham Young University, United States
Abstract: Summary form only given. We have observed recombination into a large range of Rydberg levels in an ultracold plasma. The plasma is created by two-photon ionization of laser-trapped and -cooled metastable xenon atoms. By changing the intensity and detuning of the ionizing laser pulse, the initial temperature and density of the plasma can be varied. This allows us to access plasma coupling parameters (???) between 0.1 and 5. In this range of values, we previously reported unexplained heating of the expanding cloud, between 10 and 100 ???s after creation of the plasma. The recently observed recombination appears to provide much of the extra energy responsible for this behavior. The recombined atoms, up to 20% of the created plasma, populate energy levels down to n=40. They survive for ?1 ms indicating that high angular momentum states are present. However, standard scaling laws for three-body recombination do not agree with the observed dynamics. Furthermore, Rydberg atom formation is incomplete at the time when the plasma expansion velocity has reached its maximum value. Various effects are under consideration as possible remedies to these inconsistencies. © 2001 Optical Soc. Of America.

Affiliations: Univ Hannover, Hannover, Germany

Abstract: The investigation of coherent superposition states for atoms interacting with external potential allows a completely new class of experiments directed towards coherent trapping and guiding of neutral atoms. This paper discusses the study on the creation and decay of superpositions of different components of the center-of-mass wavefunction of rubidium atoms in a one-dimensional near-resonant optical lattice.

Abstract: A new echo technique to access the coherent and dissipative dynamics of atomic wave packet oscillations in trapping potentials was experimentally and systematically validated. By using this technique, the coherence time of wave packet oscillations in strongly confining dipole potentials was measured in a regime that was previously inaccessible.

name: DUMKE Rainer
Authors: Buchkremer F.B.J., Dumke R., Buggle Ch., Birkl G., Ertmer W.
Title: Low-cost setup for generation of 3 GHz frequency difference phase-locked laser light
Affiliations: Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Welfengarten 1, D-30167 Hannover, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Buchkremer, F.B.J., Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Welfengarten 1, D-30167 Hannover, Germany; Dumke, R., Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Welfengarten 1, D-30167 Hannover, Germany; Buggle, Ch., Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Welfengarten 1, D-30167 Hannover, Germany; Birkl, G., Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Welfengarten 1, D-30167 Hannover, Germany; Ertmer, W., Institut für Quantenoptik, Universität Hannover, Welfengarten 1, D-30167 Hannover, Germany
Abstract: We have devised an all-optical setup for the generation of two phase-locked laser fields with a frequency difference of 3 GHz using only standard optics and two acousto-optical frequency shifters, that are operated at 253 MHz in sixtupel pass. The spectral width of the beat frequency is measured to be 300 Hz (full width at half maximum) limited by the resolution bandwidth of the spectrum analyzer. We routinely obtain an overall efficiency of more than 15% and demonstrate that the frequency shifted light can be further amplified by injecting it into additional "slave" lasers. This setup provides a low-cost alternative over conventional methods to generate laser fields with difference frequencies in the GHz domain, as for example, used in laser spectroscopy, laser cooling and trapping, and coherent manipulation of atomic quantum states. © 2000 American Institute of Physics.

name: DUMKE Rainer
Authors: Buchkremer F.B.J., Dumke R., Birkl G., Ertmer W.
Title: Atom optics with microfabricated optical elements
Source title: IQEC, International Quantum Electronics Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Universitaet Hannover, Hannover, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Buchkremer, F.B.J., Universitaet Hannover, Hannover, Germany; Dumke, R., Universitaet Hannover, Hannover, Germany; Birkl, G., Universitaet Hannover, Hannover, Germany; Ertmer, W., Universitaet Hannover, Hannover, Germany
Abstract: The application of microfabricated optical elements and magnetic structures will cause a significant advance in the applicability of atom optics and atom interferometry. The newly emerging field of ATom Optics with MICro-Structures (ATOMICS) is directed towards microfabrication of atom optical elements for manipulation, storage, and guiding of neutral atoms as well as miniaturization of incoherent and coherent sources of ultracold atoms. As a second step, the integration of these components with laser sources and efficient detectors in a single device should be achievable.
Index Keywords: Interferometry; Laser optics; Microstructure; Quantum theory; Atom optics with microfabricated optical elements (ATOMICS); Particle optics

Source title: IQEC, International Quantum Electronics Conference Proceedings

Abstract: The coherent superposition states for atoms superposition states for atoms interacting with external potentials were investigated, which allows a completely new class of experiments directed towards coherent trapping and guiding of neutral atoms. In addition, the process of decoherence, the collapse of superposition states, is one of the basic concepts for the understanding of the connection between classical and quantum physics. these investigations are of significant importance for trapping and guiding of individual ultracold atoms as well as coherent samples in dipole potentials. In addition, attempts to use atoms trapped in optical lattices for quantum computational purposes further stimulate the interest in the relevant decoherence properties.

name: FAN Hongjin
Authors: Tiep N.H., Ku Z., Dr., Fan H.J.
Title: Recent Advances in Improving the Stability of Perovskite Solar Cells
Affiliations: School of Physical and Mathematical Sciences, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, Singapore; Energy Research Institute NTU, Interdisciplinary Graduate School, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Tiep, N.H., School of Physical and Mathematical Sciences, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, Singapore, Energy Research Institute NTU, Interdisciplinary Graduate School, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, Singapore; Ku, Z., Dr., School of Physical and Mathematical Sciences, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, Singapore; Fan, H.J., School of Physical and Mathematical Sciences, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, Singapore
Abstract: Organometal trihalide perovskites have recently emerged as promising materials for low-cost, high-efficiency solar cells. In less than five years, the efficiency of perovskite solar cells (PSC) has been updated rapidly as a result of new strategies adopted in their fabrication process, including device structure, interfacial engineering, chemical compositional tuning, and crystallization kinetics control. To date, the best PSC efficiency has reached 20.1%, which is close to that of single crystal silicon solar cells. However, the stability of PSC devices is still unsatisfactory and is the main bottleneck impeding their commercialization. Here, we summarize recent studies on the degradation mechanisms of organometal trihalide perovskites in PSC devices, and the strategies for stability improvement. © 2015 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim.
Author Keywords: air stability; mesoscopic solar cells; organic-inorganic lead halides; perovskite solar cells

name: FAN Hongjin
Authors: Xu Z., Lin Y., Yin M., Zhang H., Cheng C., Lu L., Xue X., Fan H.J., Chen X., Li D.
Title: Understanding the Enhancement Mechanisms of Surface Plasmon-Mediated Photoelectrochemical Electrodes: A Case Study on Au Nanoparticle Decorated TiO<inf>2</inf> Nanotubes
Affiliations: Shanghai Advanced Research Institute, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 99 Haike Road, Zhangjiang Hi-Tech Park,Pudong, Shanghai, China; University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China; Shanghai Key Laboratory of Special Artificial Microstructure Materials and Technology, School of Physics Science and Engineering, Tongji University, Shanghai, China; Division of Physics and Applied Physics, School of Physical and Mathematical Sciences, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Xu, Z., Shanghai Advanced Research Institute, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 99 Haike Road, Zhangjiang Hi-Tech Park,Pudong, Shanghai, China, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China; Lin, Y., Shanghai Advanced Research Institute, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 99 Haike Road, Zhangjiang Hi-Tech Park,Pudong, Shanghai, China; Yin, M., Shanghai Advanced Research Institute, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 99 Haike Road, Zhangjiang Hi-Tech Park,Pudong, Shanghai, China; Zhang, H., Shanghai Key Laboratory of Special Artificial Microstructure Materials and Technology, School of Physics Science and Engineering, Tongji University, Shanghai, China; Cheng, C., Shanghai Key Laboratory of Special Artificial Microstructure Materials and Technology, School of Physics Science and Engineering, Tongji University, Shanghai, China; Lu, L., Shanghai Advanced Research Institute, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 99 Haike Road, Zhangjiang Hi-Tech Park,Pudong, Shanghai, China; Xue, X., Shanghai Advanced Research Institute, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 99 Haike Road, Zhangjiang Hi-Tech Park,Pudong, Shanghai, China; Fan, H.J., Division of Physics and Applied Physics, School of Physical and Mathematical Sciences, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore; Chen, X., Shanghai Advanced Research Institute, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 99 Haike Road, Zhangjiang Hi-Tech Park,Pudong, Shanghai, China; Li, D., Shanghai Advanced Research Institute, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 99 Haike Road, Zhangjiang Hi-Tech Park,Pudong, Shanghai, China
Abstract: Surface plasmon resonance (SPR) enhancement in photocatalyst and photovoltaics has been widely studied and different enhancement mechanisms have been established based on different heterostructure interface configurations. This work is intended to unveil the mechanisms behind charge or energy transfer in different plasmonic configurations of metal particle-semiconductor interfaces, especially with a dielectric layer. For this purpose, a series of composite photoelectrodes based on anodic TiO<inf>2</inf> nanotube (TONT) backbones coated with Au, Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3,</inf> or both are designed and characterized systematically. In conjunction with both experimental measurements and numerical simulations, it is revealed that in the TONT-Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>-Au electrode system (i.e., a thin nonconductive spacer between semiconductor and metal), the enhancement is dominantly governed by SPR-mediated hot-electron injection rather than conventional-thought near-field electromagnetic enhancement. Among all configurations, the TONT-Au-Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> electrode shows the best photoresponse in both UV and visible regions. The superior visible light response of the TONT-Au-Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> electrode is ascribed to the Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> intensified local electromagnetic field that enhances the hot-electron injection through the TiO<inf>2</inf>-Au interface, and an effective surface passivation by the Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> coating. With the presence of a nonconductive spacer, the enhancement mechanism of TONT (TiO<inf>2</inf> nanotubes)-Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>-Au plasmonic electrodes is dominantly governed by surface plasmon resonance (SPR)-mediated hot-electron injection rather than near-field electromagnetic enhancement. The superior visible light response of the TONT-Au-Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> electrode is ascribed to the Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> intensified local electromagnetic field that enhances the hot-electron injection process, and an effective surface passivation by the Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> coating. © 2015 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim.
Author Keywords: anodic titanium oxide nanotubes; photoelectrochemical water splitting; SPR-mediated hot-electron injection; surface passivation; surface plasmon resonance

Abstract: A new type of hierarchical anatase TiO<inf>2</inf> microcage is obtained via an in situ topotactic transformation from prefabricated CaTiO<inf>3</inf> microcages. The TiO<inf>2</inf> microcages are composed of 3D perpendicular nanocrystals with six equivalent side faces that are dominated by anatase {001}<inf>A</inf> facets. As an anode material these unique anatase TiO<inf>2</inf> microcages exhibit high-rate lithium ion storage and long-cycling stability. © 2015 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim.
Author Keywords: isofacet; lithium ion batteries; microcages; titanate; topotactic synthesis

Abstract: Organic-inorganic heterostructures are an emerging topic that is very interesting for optoelectronics. Here, non-conventional p-n junctions are investigated using organic rubrene single crystal and 2D MoS<inf>2</inf> as the p- and n-type semiconducting materials, respectively. The current-rectifying behavior is clearly observed in the junction device. The rectification ratio can be electrically tuned by the gate voltage due to the 2D nature of the heterostructure. The devices also show good photoresponse properties with a photoresponsivity of ?500 mA W-1 and a fast response time. These findings suggest a new route to facilitate the design of nanoelectronic and optoelectronic devices based on layered inorganics and organics. © 2015 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim.
Author Keywords: 2D materials; MoS<inf>2</inf>; organic-inorganic hybrids; photoresponse; van der Waals heterojunctions
Index Keywords: Electric rectifiers; Molybdenum compounds; Optoelectronic devices; Semiconductor junctions; Single crystals; Van der Waals forces; Fast response time; Organic-inorganic heterostructures; Organic-inorganic hybrid; Photoresponses; Rectification ratio; Rectifying behaviors; Semiconducting materials; Van der waals; Heterojunctions

Affiliations: NOVITAS, Nanoelectronics Centre of Excellence, School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, Singapore; School of Physical and Mathematical Sciences, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, Singapore

Abstract: Hierarchical three-dimensional carbon nanowire arrays on carbon cloth have been developed as an efficient flexible nanostructure current collector for TiO<inf>2</inf> based anodes. This unique electrode exhibits not only ?300 times higher mass loading than that of 2D planar substrates, but also high reversible capacity, remarkable rate capability and cycling stability (up to 8000 cycles). © 2015 The Royal Society of Chemistry.

name: FAN Hongjin
Authors: Zhu C., Yang P., Chao D., Wang X., Zhang X., Chen S., Tay B.K., Huang H., Zhang H., Mai W., Fan H.J.
Title: All Metal Nitrides Solid-State Asymmetric Supercapacitors
Affiliations: School of Physical and Mathematical Sciences, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, Singapore; Singapore Institute of Manufacturing Technology, 71 Nanyang Drive, Singapore, Singapore; Department of Physics and Siyuan Laboratory, Jinan University, Guangzhou, China; School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, 50 Nanyang Avenue, Singapore, Singapore; School of Materials Science and Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore

Abstract: Two metal nitrides, TiN porous layers and Fe<inf>2</inf>N nanoparticles, are grown uniformly with the assistance of atomic layer deposition on vertically aligned graphene nanosheets and used as the cathode and anode for solid-state supercapacitors, respectively. Full cells are constructed and show good flexibility, high-rate capability, and 98% capacitance retention after 20 000 cycles. © 2015 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim.
Author Keywords: flexible energy storage; graphene nanosheets; metal nitrides; solid-state supercapacitors; vertical graphene
